block_list.text: And then you can fine tune models to be very precise about the kinds of inputs and outputs that they expect and have these models start working in, in concert together.
And you know, models that are checking the outputs of other models, realizing when something doesn't make sense, asking it to try again.
And so like that ends up being how we get a ton of value out of our own models internally.

It's like specific use cases and orchestrations of models together, designed sort of working in concert to do specific tasks, which again, going back to like reasoning about how we work as humans, how do we do complex things as humans?
You have different people who often have different skill sets, and they work together to accomplish a hard task.
I can't let you guys get away without telling us something about the future and what's coming.
And so you don't have to give us release dates.
I understand you don't know.
But if you, if you look out, I think the furthest anyone can look out in AI right now is like, tell me if you can see the future.
But like, let's say like six months, 12 months, like what's an experience that you imagine is going to be possible or prevalent?
I think a lot about like 2 breaking the well, I think a lot about this all the time, but like the two maybe 2 words to be like plant seeds in in everybody's mind.
Like 1 is proactivity.
Like how do the models become more proactive?
Like once they know about you and they're monitoring, like they're reading your e-mail in a good, not creepy way.
And they're like, because you authorize them too.
And then they like, you know, spot an interesting trend or you start your day with something that's a like like a proactive, like recap of what's going on, some conversations you're going to have.
I pre did some research for you.
Hey, your next meeting is coming up.
Like here's what you might want to talk about.
I saw you have this like presentation coming up.
Here's the first draft that I put together.
Like that kind of proactivity, I think is going to be really, really powerful.
And then the other part is being more asynchronous.
So like, I think 01 is like early UI in this exploration, which is like it's going to do a lot
and it's going to tell you kind of what it's going to do along the way.
And like you can sit there and wait for it, but you could also like be like, it's going to think for a while.
I'm going to go like do something else, maybe tab back.
Maybe it like can tell me when it's done.
Like, yeah, expanding the time horizon, both in terms of like, you didn't ask a question, it just told you something.
I think that's going to be interesting.
And then you did ask a question and it can be like, great.
Like I'm going to go reason about it.
I'm going to go research it.
I might have to ask another human about it, like, and then I'm going to like maybe come up with my first answer.
I'm going to vet that answer.
You'll hear back from me in like an hour.
Like breaking free of those like constraints of like expecting an answer immediately.
I think we'll let you do things like, hey, I have this like whole like mini project plan, like go flesh it out.
Or like not just like I want you to like change this one thing on the screen, but like fix this bug for me.
Like take my PRD and like adapt it for these new market conditions.
Like adapt it for these three different marketing conditions that emerge.
Like being able to push those dimensions I think is what I'm personally most excited about on the product side.
Yeah, I completely agree with all of that.
And it's the models are going to get smarter at an accelerating rate, I think, which is also part of how all of that comes to pass.
Another thing that will be really exciting is seeing the models able to interact in all the same ways that we as humans interact.
You know, right now you mostly type to these things and, you know, I mostly type to a lot of my friends on WhatsApp and other things, but I also speak, I also can see.
And we just, we launched this advanced voice mode relatively recently.
I was in, I was in Korea and Japan having conversations.
And I would just, I would often be with somebody with whom I had no common language whatsoever.
Before this, we could not have said a word to each other.
And instead I was like, hey, Chachi BT I want you to act as a translator.
When I say something in English, I want you to say it in Korean.
And when you hear something in Korean, say it back to me in English.
And all of a sudden, I had this universal translator and I was having business conversations with another person, and it was magical.

And you think what that can do, like, not just in a business context, but think about people's willingness to travel to new places if you don't ever have to be worried about not speaking the language.
And you've got this, like, Star Trek universal translator in your pocket, you know?
And so experiences like that, I think it's going to become commonplace fast.
But it's magical.
And I'm excited about that in combination with all the stuff Mike was just saying.
Oh.
One of my favorite pastimes now or just, you know, since a voice mode release is actually watching.
There's a genre of TikTok of this just speaks to how old I am.

Like there's a genre of TikTok where you just like, it's just young people talking to voice mode, like pouring their heart out using in all these ways where I'm like, Oh my God, like there's this old term being like a digitally native or mobile native.
And I'm like, I like pretty strongly believe in this AI thing.
And I would not think to interact in this way.
But people who are 14 years old are like, well, I expect the AI to be able to do that.
And I love that.
Have you ever given it to your kids?
I haven't yet.
My kids are like five and seven knows them.
So we'll but we'll get there.
I mean mine are 8:00 and 10:00 but like on a car ride they'll be like can I talk to ChatGPT?
Yes, and they will ask it the most bizarre things.
They will just have weirdo conversations with it.
But they're perfectly happy talking to an AI.

Yeah, actually one of my favorite experiences and maybe we'll close and ask you for like the most surprising behavior, kids or not, is like when my parents read to me, like I got, I was lucky if I got to choose the book and it wasn't my dad being like, we're going to read this physics study I'm interested in, right?
My kids, I don't know if it's just like parenting in the Bay Area, but my kids are like, OK, mom, make the images right.
I want to tell a story about the dragon Unicorn in this setting.
I'm going to tell you exactly how it's going to happen.
Create it in real time.
And I'm like, that's a big ask.
I'm glad you believe and like know that's possible, but it's it's a wild way to like create your own entertainment.
So what is the most surprising behaviour you've seen in your own products recently?
I think it's a behaviour and a relationship, like people really start understanding the nuance of like what Claude is or just like a new revenge of the model.
And it's like they get the nuance.
Like it's like, I guess the behaviour is like almost befriending or like really like developing a lot of like two way empathy around what's happening.

And then like the model is like, oh, you know, the new model like felt like it was smarter, but maybe a little more distant, but maybe, you know, and it's like, it's like that kind of like nuance, which like you like, like it's, it's given me as a product person a lot more empathy around like you're not just shipping a product, you're shipping like intelligence and intelligence and empathy are like what makes like interpersonal relationships important.
And if somebody showed up and they're like, I was upgraded, like I say, you know, I scored 2% higher on this math score, but like I'm different in this way.
You'd be like, oh, I got to adapt now and maybe, you know, be a little worried about it.
So like that, that's been an interesting journey for me, like understanding the mentality for people when they're using our products.
Yeah, model behaviour is absolutely a product role.
Like the, the personality of the model is, is key and there are interesting questions around how much should it customize versus how much should you know?
Open AI have one personality and Claude has some distinct personality.
And are people going to use one versus the other because they happen to like it?
But I mean, that's a that's a very human thing, right?
We're friends with different people because we happen to like different people better than others.
And it's, that's an interesting thing to, to think about.
We did something recently and.
It sort of went viral on Twitter.
People started asking the model based on everything you know about me, based on all of our past interactions, you know what, what would you say about me?
And the model will will respond and it will like give you give it a description of what it, you know, kind of thinks based on all of your past interactions.
And it is this sort of you're, you're starting to interact with it almost like some sort of person or entity in interesting ways.
And anyways, it was fascinating to see people's reaction to that.
Kevin, Mike, thank you so much for doing this and giving us a glimpse into the future.
Thank you so much.
